head.title: Spontaneous Breakdown of Translational Symmetry in Quantum Hall Systems: Crystalline Order in High Landau Levels

article.h1: Spontaneous Breakdown of Translational Symmetry in Quantum Hall Systems: Crystalline Order in High Landau Levels

span.span: F. D. M. HaldaneaùëéFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, E. H. RezayibùëèFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b}, and Kun YangcùëêFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{c}
aùëéFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}Department of Physics, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544
bùëèFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b}Department of Physics, California State University, Los Angeles, California 90032
cùëêFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{c}National High Magnetic Field Laboratory and Department of Physics, Florida State University, Tallahassee, Florida 32306

div.p: We report on results of systematic numerical studies of two-dimensional electron gas systems subject to a perpendicular magnetic field, with a high Landau level partially filled by electrons. Our results are strongly suggestive of a breakdown of translational symmetry and the presence of crystalline order in the ground state. This is in sharp contrast with the physics of the lowest and first excited Landau levels, and in good qualitative agreement with earlier Hartree-Fock studies. Experimental implications of our results are discussed.

Recently there has been considerable interest in the behavior of a two-dimensional (2D) electron gas subject to a perpendicular magnetic field, when a high Landau level (LL) (with LL index N‚â•2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:2N\geq 2) is partially filled by electrons. This is largely inspired by the recent experimental discovery[1, 2, 3] that the transport properties of the system are highly anisotropic and non-linear for LL filling fraction ŒΩ=9/2,11/2,13/2,‚ãØùúà92112132‚ãØitalic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:9 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:11 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, NUMBER:13 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:cdots\nu=9/2,11/2,13/2,\cdots. Previously, Hartree-Fock[4, 5, 6] (HF) and variational studies[7] suggested that, unlike the N=0ùëÅ0italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:0N=0 and N=1ùëÅ1italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:1N=1 LL‚Äôs (in which either incompressible fractional quantum Hall (FQH) or compressible Fermi-liquid like states are realized), in N‚â•2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:2N\geq 2 LL‚Äôs the electrons form charge density waves (CDW). In particular, at half-integral filling CDW‚Äôs break translational symmetry only in one direction and form stripes. Anisotropic transport would indeed result from such a striped (or related) structure[8, 9, 10, 11].

An outstanding issue is the nature of the ground state at high LL‚Äôs for fillings sufficiently far from the half-filled level. Koulakov, Fogler and Shklovskii[4, 5] (see also Moessner and Chalker[6]) predicted a novel crystalline phase called the ‚Äúbubble‚Äù phase with more than one electron per unit cell outside of the range ŒΩ~=0.4-0.6~ùúà0.40.6OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-nu ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6	ilde{
u}=0.4-0.6. The bubble crystal has lower energy than the Laughlin state for ŒΩ=4+1/3ùúà413italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3
u=4+1/3[7]. Experimentally, a re-entrant quantum Hall state is found near ŒΩ=4+1/4ùúà414italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4
u=4+1/4 which is quantized as a ŒΩ=4ùúà4italic-nu RELOP:equals NUMBER:4
u=4 LL plateau[1, 2, 3]. Evidently the electrons in the top-most LL are frozen out of the transport. Pinning of a crystalline structure provides a natural explanation of the re-entrant phase and would further explain the observed threshold in conduction[3]. However this is not entirely conclusive and other mechanisms for the conduction threshold are also possible[3].

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: Energy levels versus aspect ratio for quarter-filled N=2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N=2 Landau level with eight electrons and rectangular geometry. The inset is a blow-up of the low-energy spectra for aspect ratio between 0.6 and 1.0. The points at 1.1 (open circle plus x) correspond to hexagonal unit cell.

div.p: In this paper, we report on new numerical results on systems away from half-filling using the unscreened Coulomb interactions. Remarkably, our results suggest that CDW‚Äôs are formed at all filling factors we have studied, including those that would support prominent FQH states or composite fermion Fermi-liquid states in the lowest or first excited Landau levels. These CDW‚Äôs, however, have 2D structures and are no longer stripes when the filling factors are sufficiently far away from 1/212NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:21/2. They are not Wigner crystals[13] either, unless ŒΩ~~ùúàOVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-nu ARG:end\tilde{\nu} is small (below 0.2). In the intermediate filling factor range, we find each unit cell of the CDW contains more than one electron. Our results are in good agreement with the predicted bubble phase and are the first exact finite-size calculations which exhibit a crystalline state in a system with continuous translational symmetry.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: The allowed (circles) and the ground state manifold momenta (√óMULOP:times\times‚Äôs). The data is for a rectangular geometry with a‚Å¢s‚Å¢p=0.77ùëéùë†ùëù0.77italic-a italic-s italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.77asp=0.77, 8 electrons in the N=2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N=2 LL and ŒΩ~=1/4~ùúà14OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-nu ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\tilde{\nu}=1/4. The solid line is the boundary of the BZ. The superlattice reciprocal basis vectors are shown by solid arrows. The inset gives the corresponding results for an hexagonal unit cell.

div.p: We restrict the states of the electrons to a given LL, and work with periodic boundary conditions (PBC, torus geometry) as in our previous paper[12]. We also set the magnetic length to unity. To detect intrinsically preferred configurations we consider a rectangular PBC unit cell and vary its aspect ratio. The PBC plays a crucial role in removing continuous rotational symmetry, and selecting a discrete set of possible crystal orientations.

In Fig.1 we plot the energy levels of systems with Ne=8subscriptùëÅùëí8italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:8N_{e}=8 electrons in the N=2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N=2 LL at filling factor ŒΩ~=1/4~ùúà14OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-nu ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\tilde{\nu}=1/4 as a function of the aspect ratio. We also show the levels of a system with a hexagonal PBC unit cell at the right side of Fig.1. A generic feature of the spectra is the existence of a large number of low-lying states whose energies are almost degenerate, which we call the ground state manifold. The momenta of these quasi-degenerate states for rectangular geometry with aspect ratio a‚Å¢s‚Å¢p=0.77ùëéùë†ùëù0.77italic-a italic-s italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.77asp=0.77 and hexagonal geometry are shown in Fig.2; they form a 2D superlattice structure, which for the rectangular geometry have the super cell vectors ùêõ1=2‚Å¢a‚Å¢e^x-b‚Å¢e^ysubscriptùêõ12ùëésubscript^ùëíùë•ùëèsubscript^ùëíùë¶bold-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-a OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-b OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf b}_{1}=2a\hat{e}_{x}-b\hat{e}_{y}, and ùêõ2=2‚Å¢b‚Å¢e^ysubscriptùêõ22ùëèsubscript^ùëíùë¶bold-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-b OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf b}_{2}=2b\hat{e}_{y}. Where, a=2‚Å¢œÄ/L1ùëé2ùúãsubscriptùêø1italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda=2\pi/L_{1}, and b=2‚Å¢œÄ/L2ùëè2ùúãsubscriptùêø2italic-b RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb=2\pi/L_{2}. L1subscriptùêø1italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{1}, and L2subscriptùêø2italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{2} are the dimensions of the unit cell (L1√óL2=2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢NŒ¶subscriptùêø1subscriptùêø22ùúãsubscriptùëÅŒ¶italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{1}\times L_{2}=2\pi N_{\Phi}, NŒ¶subscriptùëÅŒ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\Phi} is the total flux quanta in the system). The area per wavevector in the Brillouin zone (BZ) is a‚Å¢b=(2‚Å¢œÄ)2/Aùëéùëèsuperscript2ùúã2ùê¥italic-a italic-b RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-pi CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-Aab=(2\pi)^{2}/A, where Aùê¥italic-AA is the (real space) area of the system.

There are similarities as well as important differences between these spectra and those of half-filled high LL‚Äôs[12] with stripe order. As in the stripe case[12], the large quasi-degeneracy of the ground state manifold is an indication of broken translational symmetry[15]. The difference here is that (i) the degeneracy is much larger and (ii) the momenta of the low-lying states form 2D instead of 1D arrays. These new features indicate that the translational symmetry is broken in both directions and the ground state is a 2D CDW. In the stripe state, on the other hand, the translational symmetry is only broken in the direction perpendicular to the stripes. Therefore the degeneracy is smaller and the momenta of the low-lying states form a 1D array.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: A 2D plot of the peaks of the projected (or guiding center) charge susceptibility œá‚Å¢(ùê™)ùúíùê™italic-chi OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:)\chi({\bf q}) at reciprocal lattice vectors, for a system with Ne=8subscriptùëÅùëí8italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:8N_{e}=8 at ŒΩ~=1/4~ùúà14OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-nu ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\tilde{\nu}=1/4, rectangular geometry with a=0.77ùëé0.77italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.77a=0.77. The size of the circles give an indication of the height of the peak at that point. Only responses above 100 have been plotted as solid circles. The zone boundaries are not within the range of the figure. The largest circle corresponds to 16491. The inset gives the results for a hexagonal unit cell. The √óMULOP:times\times‚Äôs are the allowed wavevectors.

div.p: The momenta of the states in the ground state manifold are the reciprocal lattice vectors of the bubble crystal. Transforming to the direct lattice vectors, we obtain ùêö1=œÄ/a‚Å¢e^xsubscriptùêö1ùúãùëésubscript^ùëíùë•bold-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-a OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf a}_{1}=\pi/a\hat{e}_{x} and ùêö2=œÄ/2‚Å¢a‚Å¢e^x+œÄ/b‚Å¢e^ysubscriptùêö2ùúã2ùëésubscript^ùëíùë•ùúãùëèsubscript^ùëíùë¶bold-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-a OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-b OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-e ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf a}_{2}=\pi/2a\hat{e}_{x}+\pi/b\hat{e}_{y}. For the optimum system, with a‚Å¢s‚Å¢pùëéùë†ùëùitalic-a italic-s italic-pasp=0.77, we obtain a1=8.08subscriptùëé18.08italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:8.08a_{1}=8.08, a2=7.42subscriptùëé27.42italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:7.42a_{2}=7.42, and œï=57‚àòitalic-œïsuperscript57italic-phi RELOP:equals NUMBER:57 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\phi=57^{\circ}. This is very close to a triangular lattice. In the case of hexagonal PBC unit cell, both the reciprocal superlattice and its direct lattice are triangular.

The number NDsubscriptùëÅùê∑italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{D} of distinct quasi-degenerate ground states allows the number NbsubscriptùëÅùëèitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{b} of bubbles in the system, and hence the number MùëÄitalic-MM = Ne/NbsubscriptùëÅùëísubscriptùëÅùëèitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{e}/N_{b} of electrons per bubble, to be immediately obtained through the relation Nb‚Å¢NDsubscriptùëÅùëèsubscriptùëÅùê∑italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{b}N_{D} = N¬Ø2superscript¬ØùëÅ2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{N}^{2}, where N¬Ø¬ØùëÅOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end\bar{N} is the highest common divisor of NesubscriptùëÅùëíitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{e} and NŒ¶subscriptùëÅŒ¶italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\Phi}. In our case, N¬Ø¬ØùëÅOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end\bar{N} = NesubscriptùëÅùëíitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{e} = 8, and ND=16subscriptùëÅùê∑16italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:16N_{D}=16, which gives Nb=4subscriptùëÅùëè4italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4N_{b}=4 and M=2ùëÄ2italic-M RELOP:equals NUMBER:2M=2[16]. The Wigner crystal would correspond to Nb=NesubscriptùëÅùëèsubscriptùëÅùëíitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{b}=N_{e} and M=1ùëÄ1italic-M RELOP:equals NUMBER:1M=1. In general[17], there are N¬Ø2superscript¬ØùëÅ2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{N}^{2} distinct values of the total momentum quantum number, which define a BZ of area (2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢N¬Ø)2/Asuperscript2ùúã¬ØùëÅ2ùê¥OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-pi OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-A(2\pi\bar{N})^{2}/A. If translational symmetry is broken, the area of the BZ of the superlattice is then (2‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢N¬Ø)2/A‚Å¢NDsuperscript2ùúã¬ØùëÅ2ùê¥subscriptùëÅùê∑OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-pi OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-A italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(2\pi\bar{N})^{2}/AN_{D}, which must be (2‚Å¢œÄ)2/(A/Nb)superscript2ùúã2ùê¥subscriptùëÅùëèOPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-pi CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-A MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(2\pi)^{2}/(A/N_{b}), where A/Nbùê¥subscriptùëÅùëèitalic-A MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA/N_{b} is the area per bubble; hence Nb‚Å¢NDsubscriptùëÅùëèsubscriptùëÅùê∑italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{b}N_{D} = N¬Ø2superscript¬ØùëÅ2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-N ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{N}^{2}.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: A 3D plot of the guiding center structure factor S0‚Å¢(ùê™)subscriptùëÜ0ùê™italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:)S_{0}({\bf q}) (same system as Fig.3). The signature of the hexagonal lattice is seen in the near six-fold symmetry of the peaks.

div.p: We next turn to the density response functions. In Fig.3 we show the projected ground state charge susceptibility[12] œá‚Å¢(ùê™)ùúíùê™italic-chi OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:)\chi({\bf q}) of one of the optimum rectangular and hexagonal systems described above. The calculation takes into account the contributions from the two lowest energy states in each symmetry subspace; this is an excellent approximation in view of the fact that the response function is dominated by low energy states because of the energy denominator. We note that œá‚Å¢(ùê™)ùúíùê™italic-chi OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:)\chi({\bf q}) exhibits a strong response at the reciprocal lattice vectors (Bragg condition); the background at other wave vectors (shown by √óMULOP:times\times‚Äôs in Fig.3) are negligible compared to these responses. The origin of the strong response lies in the approximate degeneracy among the states forming the ground state manifold. The system responds very strongly to a potential modulation with a wave vector that connects the ground state to one of the low lying states (which must be a reciprocal lattice vector) because of the small energy denominator. This is also another reason why there must be one low-lying state for each reciprocal lattice vector. A second notable feature is the almost hexagonal symmetry of the response, despite the fact that the PBC geometry used in this case was rectangular. This indicates that the bubbles tend to form a triangular lattice, in agreement with the predictions of HF theory.

The tendency toward forming a triangular lattice is also seen in the ‚Äúguiding center (GC) static structure factor‚Äù S0‚Å¢(ùê™)subscriptùëÜ0ùê™italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:)S_{0}({\bf q})[12], which we present as a 3D plot in Fig.4. Here we see sharp peaks with an approximate six-fold symmetry at the primary reciprocal lattice vectors, indicating the presence of strong density correlation at these wave vectors in the ground state.

figure.figcaption: Figure 5: Real-space ‚Äúprojected density‚Äù (guiding center) correlation function, derived from Fig.4. A 2D contour plot is also included below the 3D plot.
Figure 6: N=2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N=2 Landau level full electron density correlations (relative to a guiding center), derived from Fig.4.

div.p: In Fig.5 and Fig.6 we plot ground state ‚Äúprojected density‚Äù correlation functions in real space. These describe correlations relative to the GC (not the coordinate) of a particle. The first is the Fourier transform (FT) of S0‚Å¢(ùê™)‚Å¢exp‚Å°(-q2/2)subscriptùëÜ0ùê™superscriptùëû22italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:) OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)S_{0}({\bf q})\exp(-q^{2}/2), which is the electron density of an equivalent lowest-LL system, and gives information on the spatial distribution of GC‚Äôs. The second is the FT of S0‚Å¢(ùê™)‚Å¢[LN‚Å¢(q2/2)]2‚Å¢exp‚Å°(-q2/2)subscriptùëÜ0ùê™superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptùêøùëÅsuperscriptùëû222superscriptùëû22italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bold-q CLOSE:) OPEN:[ italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)S_{0}({\bf q})[L_{N}(q^{2}/2)]^{2}\exp(-q^{2}/2) with N=2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N=2 (LNsubscriptùêøùëÅitalic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:endL_{N} is a Laguerre polynomial): this (plus the uniform density of the filled LL‚Äôs) represents the actual electron density.

In Fig.5 the presence of four bubbles and the relative orientation of the bubbles can be clearly seen and there is strong crystalline order of the GC distribution. The central peak contains two electrons, one of which is the particle with the GC at the origin. For N>0ùëÅ0italic-N RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0N>0, as in Fig.6, only weak order is displayed by the actual electron density, because of the averaging effect of the cyclotron motion around the GC‚Äôs. It is the guiding centers of the electrons that form bubbles as anticipated in reference 7 (Fig.1). The electrons themselves manage to stay apart to lower the Coulomb repulsion, in spite of the clustering of their GC‚Äôs.

figure.figcaption: Figure 7: Spectra of systems with eight electrons at ŒΩ~=1/3~ùúà13OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-nu ARG:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:3\tilde{\nu}=1/3 in the N=2ùëÅ2italic-N RELOP:equals NUMBER:2N=2 LL, with rectangular geometry and various aspect ratios. The inset plots the momenta of the low-lying states for a‚Å¢s‚Å¢pùëéùë†ùëùitalic-a italic-s italic-pasp = 0.75, in the same way as Fig. 2.

div.p: We have benefited from stimulating discussions with J. P. Eisenstein, K. B. Cooper and M. P. Lilly. We thank B. I. Shklovskii and M. M. Fogler for helpful comments. This work was supported by NSF DMR-9420560 and DMR-0086191 (E.H.R.), DMR-9809483 (F.D.M.H.), DMR-9971541, and the Sloan Foundation (K.Y.). E.H.R. acknowledges the hospitality of ITP Santa Barbara, supported by NSF-PHY94-07194, where part of the work was performed.
